lexUnit.name: sympathy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: feelings of pity and sorrow for someone else's misfortune

sentence.text: Throughout the litigation in Webb there is an open feeling of sympathy towards the employer in this type of situation and the problem has been posed in terms of the unusual facts of the case .
There was no thanks , no expression of sympathy for what Anna had suffered .
Messily directed by John Schlesinger , it fails to evoke admiration or sympathy for its characters .
It is this " pathetic " quality in Antoine Bloye 's character which undoubtedly elicits the sympathy of the reader and at the same time has significant implications at the historical level .
She cried and wailed into Sally-Anne 's skirt so pitifully that Sally-Anne 's own fear of the brute before her was lost in sympathy for his wretched victim .
But by the end she chose to overplay her hand and lost the sympathy of those who could have saved her from her last indignities -- though perhaps not from the bottle .
In William Waldegrave the DoE had acquired an intelligent minister with a genuine sympathy for the environment .
He went even further than that ; when Bradlaugh was imprisoned during the oath struggle , Headlam sent him a telegram reading : ` Accept my warmest sympathy .
` Someone must have hurt you very much , " Claudia said , her voice warm with sympathy .
Roseberry 's musical background might go some way to explaining her ` good ear " as well as her sympathy for musicians trying to catch the attention of A & R departments .
Even those of us who have had a sneaking sympathy for Marina 's parents find their inability to accept their grandchild hard to comprehend .
Mr Lewis said they had great sympathy for the flood victims .
I ca n't say I feel much sympathy for them .
All the newspapers carried the story and there was a wave of public sympathy for him .
One has sympathy with adoptive parents who want ` a clean break " , and no more contact , ever , with the natural mother .
At second hand we could have enjoyed the thrill of dangerous living or shown magnanimous sympathy with the victims of oppression .
We have every sympathy with the plight of those infected with HIV as a result of NHS blood or tissue transfer .
I tell him about the cramps , feeling like a child who has fallen and cut herself , demanding sympathy .
Though Polly had little sympathy for Clive after what he had put her through , this merciless dismissal of another man 's entire future made her skin crawl .
Malcolm Fortune , defending said the practice extended its sympathy to the family .
Far from rendering them subject to ridicule , such a stress is one of the best ways to hold an audience and gain sympathy .
